metadata.domain: Probabilistic seismic hazard analysis (PSHA) for tailings storage facilities in stable continental regions

entries.definition: A systematic methodology for quantifying seismic hazard by integrating uncertainties in earthquake location, magnitude, and ground motion characteristics to calculate the probability of exceeding specified ground motion levels at a site.

A tectonic region characterized by ancient cratonic rocks with low rates of crustal deformation, absence of active plate boundaries, and infrequent diffuse seismicity, typically within continental interiors.

A geographic-tectonic designation for the stable continental region east of the Rocky Mountains in North America, characterized by intraplate seismicity and used as a reference domain for ground motion model development.

A large physiographic province in North America consisting of exposed Precambrian igneous and high-grade metamorphic rocks, representing one of the oldest known cratons containing rocks dating back several billion years.
A large stable mass of ancient continental lithosphere forming the core of the North American continent, characterized by thick crust and low seismicity rates.

A region of continental crust containing very old rocks (typically more than 1 billion years), representing tectonically stable parts of the lithosphere that have persisted through multiple cycles of continental rifting and basin formation.
A representation of earthquake sources used in PSHA that defines spatial distribution, magnitude-frequency relationships, and maximum magnitude constraints for potential earthquakes.

aliases: sixth-generation seismic hazard model of Canada
entries.definition: The sixth-generation seismic hazard model developed by Natural Resources Canada for southeastern Canada, consisting of multiple areal source zones and magnitude-frequency distributions implemented in the 2020 National Building Code of Canada.
A seismic source zone defined by geographic boundaries rather than discrete faults, representing distributed background seismicity where earthquakes can occur at any location within the defined area.
An empirical or semi-empirical equation that predicts ground motion intensity measures as a function of earthquake magnitude, source-to-site distance, site conditions, and other parameters.
The Next Generation Attenuation project for Central and Eastern North America, producing 17 ground motion models specifically developed for stable continental regions.

A major Archean-age structural complex marking the boundary between the Abitibi and Pontiac sub-provinces in the Superior Province, located approximately 10 km from the Louvicourt site but currently seismically inactive.
A geological sub-province within the Superior Province of the Canadian Shield, characterized by Archean greenstone belts and associated plutonic rocks.
The largest Archean craton in the Canadian Shield, formed between 3.0 and 2.6 billion years ago, encompassing much of the northern Great Lakes region.
Earthquake activity occurring within the interior of tectonic plates away from plate boundaries, typically characterized by low rates and diffuse spatial distribution.
Earthquake activity that is spatially scattered without clear association to mapped geological structures, characteristic of stable continental regions.
The process of decomposing total probabilistic seismic hazard to identify the relative contributions from different earthquake scenarios characterized by magnitude, distance, and epsilon values.
The probability that a specified ground motion level will be exceeded at least once during a one-year period, typically expressed as a reciprocal (e.g., 1/475 for 10% in 50 years).
The average time interval between exceedances of a specified ground motion level, mathematically the reciprocal of the annual exceedance probability.
A magnitude scale based on seismic moment, providing a physically-based measure of earthquake size that does not saturate for large earthquakes.
The horizontal distance between an earthquake epicenter (surface projection of rupture initiation) and a site of interest.
The shortest distance from a site to the earthquake rupture surface, used in ground motion models as a key distance metric.

The number of standard deviations by which an observed or target ground motion differs from the median ground motion predicted by a ground motion model, representing inter-event and intra-event variability.
The natural vibration period of a single-degree-of-freedom oscillator used to characterize frequency content of ground motion and structural response.
The maximum absolute value of ground acceleration recorded or predicted at a site during an earthquake, typically measured in units of gravitational acceleration (g).
The maximum absolute acceleration response of a single-degree-of-freedom oscillator with specified damping to an earthquake ground motion time history at a particular natural period.
The earthquake scenario (characterized by magnitude, distance, and epsilon) that contributes most significantly to seismic hazard at a specified annual exceedance probability.
A geographic region within a seismic source model characterized by relatively uniform seismicity parameters including earthquake recurrence rates and maximum magnitude.
A seismic source zone in southeastern Quebec characterized by elevated seismicity rates, identified as the largest contributor to seismic hazard at the Louvicourt site across multiple return periods.
A seismic source zone in southeastern Quebec identified as the second or third largest contributor to seismic hazard at the Louvicourt site.
A fault showing evidence of surface displacement during the Upper Pleistocene (approximately the last 126,000 years), indicating potential for future earthquake rupture.
The largest earthquake magnitude considered possible within a seismic source zone, serving as an upper bound in magnitude-frequency distributions used in PSHA.
A statistical relationship describing the rate at which earthquakes of different magnitudes occur within a seismic source, typically expressed as a Gutenberg-Richter relationship.

An empirical relationship expressing earthquake recurrence as log N = a - bM, where N is the cumulative number of earthquakes exceeding magnitude M, and a and b are constants characterizing activity rate and magnitude distribution.
A structured framework for representing and weighting alternative models, parameters, or interpretations to quantify epistemic uncertainty in PSHA.
Uncertainty arising from incomplete knowledge or data, represented in PSHA through alternative models or parameter values weighted in a logic tree framework.
A record of ground acceleration as a function of time during an earthquake, used for time-domain dynamic analysis of structures.
A response spectrum in which spectral acceleration at each period corresponds to the same annual exceedance probability, representing a smooth envelope of ground motion hazard across all periods.
The time-averaged shear wave velocity over the upper 30 meters of a site profile, used to characterize site stiffness for ground motion prediction and site amplification assessment.
The natural vibration period at which a structure or soil deposit exhibits maximum dynamic response, used to characterize structural and geotechnical dynamic behavior.

An intensity measure value (such as duration or energy) conditioned on a specified spectral shape, used to ensure ground motion selection captures appropriate duration and frequency content characteristics.
Ground motion intensity parameters beyond spectral ordinates, including cumulative absolute velocity, Arias intensity, and significant duration, used to characterize duration and energy content.
An energy-based ground motion intensity measure defined as the time integral of the square of acceleration, quantifying total energy content of a ground motion record.
An intensity measure calculated as the time integral of absolute acceleration, quantifying cumulative demand imposed by a ground motion over its entire duration.
The time interval over which a specified portion of the Arias intensity is accumulated, typically measured between 5% and 75% (D5-75) or 5% and 95% (D5-95) of total Arias intensity.
The primary earthquake characteristics of magnitude and source-to-site distance that define a representative earthquake scenario for ground motion selection.
The process of multiplying a recorded ground motion time history by a constant factor to match a target spectral shape or amplitude level.
The Next Generation Attenuation database for shallow crustal earthquakes in active tectonic regions, maintained by the Pacific Earthquake Engineering Research Center.
The depth below the surface at which an earthquake rupture initiates, used to characterize source geometry in ground motion modeling.
The shallowest depth at which earthquake rupture occurs, affecting near-source ground motion characteristics and used in some ground motion models.
The angle between a fault plane and the horizontal, ranging from 0° (horizontal) to 90° (vertical), characterizing fault geometry.
The process of evaluating or adjusting ground motion records to achieve close agreement with a target response spectrum over a specified period range.
The nth root of the product of n values, used to compute average spectral response from multiple horizontal components or multiple records in a suite.
A moment magnitude 6.1 earthquake that occurred in 1935 approximately 190 km southwest of the Louvicourt site, representing the largest historical earthquake in the regional vicinity.
An engineered structure for long-term storage of mine tailings (waste material from mineral extraction), requiring seismic stability assessment for safety.
A geologic eon spanning from approximately 4.0 to 2.5 billion years ago, during which the Earth's earliest continental crust formed.
A geologic era spanning from approximately 2.5 to 1.6 billion years ago, during which significant continental assembly occurred including formation of the Superior Province.
An ancient continental mass that forms the geological core of North America, assembled during the Paleoproterozoic from collision of Archean microcontinents.
A geological sub-province within the Superior Province of the Canadian Shield, adjacent to the Abitibi Sub-province and separated by the Cadillac-Larder Lake fault zone.
The most recent stage of the Pleistocene Epoch, spanning approximately the last 126,000 years, used as a time criterion for defining active faults in seismic hazard assessment.
Surface landforms, terrain features, or topographic expressions that may indicate recent fault activity or surface rupture.
The most recent geologic period spanning the last 2.6 million years, encompassing the Pleistocene and Holocene epochs, used as a general timeframe for assessing recent geological activity.
A seismic source represented by a specific mapped fault with defined geometry, used in PSHA when faults show evidence of being seismically active.
The most frequently occurring or highest-probability value in a probability distribution, used in disaggregation to identify the single most likely scenario contributing to hazard.
The arithmetic average of a distribution, used in disaggregation to characterize the central tendency of hazard contributions across magnitude-distance space.
The middle value of a distribution when ranked in order, representing the 50th percentile, used in disaggregation to characterize hazard contributions.
The record of past earthquake occurrences based on historical documents, instrumental recordings, and catalogs, used to characterize seismicity patterns and rates.
The frequency at which earthquakes of specified magnitudes occur within a source region, typically expressed as number of events per year.
The style of faulting that produces an earthquake, classified as strike-slip, normal, reverse, or oblique, affecting ground motion characteristics.
A style of faulting in which the hanging wall moves upward relative to the footwall along a dipping fault plane, typically associated with compressional tectonic regimes.
A style of faulting characterized by predominantly horizontal motion parallel to the fault strike, with minimal vertical displacement.
A style of faulting in which the hanging wall moves downward relative to the footwall along a dipping fault plane, typically associated with extensional tectonic regimes.
A region characterized by ongoing tectonic deformation associated with plate boundaries, exhibiting high seismicity rates and active faulting.
Alternative seismic source characterizations within the CanadaSHM6 framework, weighted in a logic tree to represent epistemic uncertainty in source zonation.
A CanadaSHM6 seismic source sub-model (H2) that defines source zones based on spatial clustering of historical earthquake locations and magnitudes.
A CanadaSHM6 seismic source sub-model (R2) that defines source zones based on geological and tectonic criteria rather than historical seismicity patterns.
A CanadaSHM6 seismic source sub-model (HY) that combines both historical seismicity patterns and geological criteria to define source zones.
Engineering analysis evaluating the stability of earth structures (such as slopes, dams, or embankments) under static and dynamic loading conditions.
A plot of maximum response (typically acceleration, velocity, or displacement) of single-degree-of-freedom oscillators with varying natural periods subjected to a ground motion time history.
The component of ground motion measured or analyzed in a horizontal direction, typically resolved into two orthogonal components for engineering analysis.
A multiplicative constant applied to a ground motion time history to adjust its amplitude to match a target spectrum or intensity level.
The range of oscillator periods for which ground motion spectral compatibility is evaluated, defined relative to the fundamental period of the structure being analyzed.
The Pacific Earthquake Engineering Research Center, a multi-institutional research center that develops and maintains ground motion databases and models.
The probability that potentially damaging earthquake ground shaking will occur at a site within a specified time period.
The Canadian model building code providing minimum requirements for building design, including seismic provisions based on the national seismic hazard model.
The Canadian federal organization responsible for geoscience research and seismic hazard assessment, developer of the CanadaSHM6 model.
A specified percentile of a probability distribution, used in PSHA to characterize uncertainty bounds around median hazard estimates.
Analysis examining how variations in input parameters affect output results, used to identify which parameters most strongly influence hazard estimates.
A physical measure of earthquake size based on the product of fault rupture area, average slip, and rock rigidity, providing the basis for moment magnitude scale.
Archean-age sequences of metamorphosed mafic to ultramafic volcanic rocks with associated sedimentary rocks, characteristic of the Abitibi Sub-province.
